text.p: These are the leading stories in Zambia's newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- President Frederick Chiluba has suspended a Lusaka high court judge and appointed a three-man tribunal headed by the anti-corruption commission chief to investigate him, state house said on Monday. No reasons were given for his supension.
- Chiluba has urged African universities to liberate themselves from foreign domination to reduce the number of "flying consultants" who depend on local expertise to prepare their reports.
- Zambia's maize ouput in 1997 is likely to drop in spite of good rains because of the late arrival of fertilisers in the country, the agriculture ministry said on Monday.
- Council workers in the southern town of Livingstone went on strike on Monday for the second time in two weeks, disrupting normal social services in the tourist resort.
- Former foreign affairs minister Vernon Mwaanga is a self-confessed drug trafficker, ministry of home affairs documents obtained by The Post have revealed.
